verse_text: And so David, having reviewed his people, appointed over them tribunes and centurions

And he placed a third part of the people under the hand of Joab, and a third part under the hand of Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, the brother of Joab, and a third part under the hand of Ittai, who was from Gath. And the king said to the people, â€œI, too, will go forth with you.

And the people responded: â€œYou shall not go out. For if we flee, there will not be great concern in them for us. Or if one half part of us will fall, they will not care much. For you are considered as one for ten thousand. Therefore, it is better that you should be in the city to strengthen us.
And the king said to them, â€œI will do whatever seems good to you.â€ Therefore, the king stood beside the gate. And the people went out by their troops, by hundreds and by thousands
And the king ordered Joab and Abishai and Ittai, saying, â€œPreserve for me the boy Absalom.â€ And all the people heard the king commanding all the leaders on behalf of Absalom
And so, the people departed into the field against Israel. And the battle took place in the forest of Ephraim
And the people of Israel were cut down in that place by the army of David. And a great slaughter occurred on that day: twenty thousand men
Now the battle in that place was dispersed over the face of all the land. And there were many more of the people whom the forest had consumed, than the sword had devoured, on that day

Then it happened that Absalom, riding on a mule, met the servants of David. And when the mule had entered under a thick and large oak tree, his head became trapped in the oak. And while he was suspended between heaven and earth, the mule on which he had been sitting continued on
Then a certain one saw this and reported it to Joab, saying, â€œI saw Absalom hanging from an oak.
And Joab said to the man who had reported it to him, â€œIf you saw him, why did you not stab him to the ground, and I would have given you ten shekels of silver and a belt?

And he said to Joab: â€œEven if you weighed out to my hands one thousand silver coins, I would never lay my hands on the son of the king. For in our hearing the king ordered you and Abishai and Ittai, saying, â€˜Keep for me the boy Absalom.
Then too, if I had acted with such audacity, against my own life, this would never have been able to be hidden from the king. And would you then have stood by my side?

And Joab said, â€œIt will not be as you wish. Instead, I will be assailing him in your sight.â€ Then he took three lances in his hand, and he fixed them in the heart of Absalom. And while he was still clinging to life upon the oak
ten young men, armor bearers of Joab, ran up, and striking him, they killed him
Then Joab sounded the trumpet, and he held back the people, lest they pursue Israel in their flight, for he was willing to spare the multitude
And they took Absalom, and they threw him into a great pit in the forest. And they piled an exceedingly great heap of stones over him. But all of Israel fled to their own tents

Now Absalom had raised up for himself, when he was still alive, a monument, which is in the Valley of the King. For he said, â€œI have no son, and so this shall be the memorial to my name.â€ And he called the monument by his own name. And it is called the Hand of Absalom, even to this day
Then Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, said, â€œI will run and report to the king that the Lord has accomplished judgment for him, from the hand of his enemies.
And Joab said to him: â€œYou shall not be the messenger on this day. Instead, you shall report on another day. I am not willing for you to give the report today, because the son of the king is dead.
Then Joab said to Hushai, â€œGo, and report to the king what you have seen.â€ Hushai reverenced Joab, and he ran

And Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, said to Joab again, â€œWhat prevents me from running after Hushai also?â€ And Joab said to him: â€œWhy do you want to run, my son? You would not be the bearer of good news.
And he responded, â€œBut what if I do run?â€ And he said to him, â€œRun.â€ Then Ahimaaz, running along a shorter way, passed Hushai
Now David was sitting between the two gates. Truly, the watchman, who was at the summit of the gate upon the wall, lifting up his eyes, saw a man running alone
And crying out, he told the king. And the king said, â€œIf he is alone, there is good news in his mouth.â€ But as he was advancing and drawing nearer
the watchman saw another man running. And so, crying out from the height, he said: â€œAnother man has appeared, running alone.â€ And the king said, â€œThis one also is a good messenger.
Then the watchman said, â€œThe running of the closest one seems like the running of Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok.â€ And the king said, â€œHe is a good man, and he arrives bearing good news.

Then, Ahimaaz, crying out, said to the king, â€œBe well, O king.â€ And reverencing the king prone on the ground before him, he said, â€œBlessed be the Lord your God, who has enclosed the men who had lifted up their hands against my lord the king.
And the king said, â€œIs there peace for the boy Absalom?â€ And Ahimaaz said: â€œI saw a great tumult, O king, when your servant Joab sent me, your servant. I know nothing else.
And the king said to him, â€œPass, and stand here.â€ And when he had passed and stood still
Hushai appeared. And approaching, he said: â€œI bear good news, my lord the king. For today the Lord has judged for you, from the hand of all who had risen up against you.

But the king said to Hushai, â€œIs there peace for the boy Absalom?â€ And responding, Hushai said to him, â€œMay the enemies of my lord the king, and all who rise against him for evil, be as the boy is.

And so the king, being greatly saddened, ascended to the upper room of the gate, and he wept. And as he went, he was speaking in this manner: â€œMy son Absalom! Absalom my son! Who can grant to me that I may die on your behalf? Absalom, my son! My son, Absalom!
